questions.question_text:
You have a web app named WebApp1.
You create a web application firewall (WAF) policy named WAF1.
You need to protect WebApp1 by using WAF1.
What should you do first?

discussion.content:
Correct answer.

WAF is supported by Application Gateway and FrontDoor both.
Answer is CORRECT

Selected Answer: A
A. Deploy an Azure Front Door.

Selected Answer: A
A is the answer.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/web-application-firewall/overview#supported-service
WAF can be deployed with Azure Application Gateway, Azure Front Door, and Azure Content Delivery Network (CDN) service from Microsoft. WAF on Azure CDN is currently under public preview. WAF has features that are customized for each specific service.

Selected Answer: A
A. Deploy an Azure Front Door.
Repeat question...correct regardless

Selected Answer: A
WAF is supported by both Application Gateway and Front Door

Supported service
WAF can be deployed with Azure Application Gateway, Azure Front Door, and Azure Content Delivery Network (CDN) service from Microsoft. WAF on Azure CDN is currently under public preview.

https://docs.microsoft.com/nl-nl/azure/web-application-firewall/overview

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription that contains an Azure SQL database named sql1.
You plan to audit sql1.
You need to configure the audit log destination. The solution must meet the following requirements:
✑ Support querying events by using the Kusto query language.
✑ Minimize administrative effort.
What should you configure?

discussion.content: Correct, key here is "Kusto query language"
On exam, May 2021.
C. On exam 4th Nov.

Selected Answer: C
C. a Log Analytics workspace

Selected Answer: C
C is the answer.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-monitor/logs/log-query-overview
Azure Monitor Logs is based on Azure Data Explorer, and log queries are written by using the same Kusto Query Language (KQL). This rich language is designed to be easy to read and author, so you should be able to start writing queries with some basic guidance.

Areas in Azure Monitor where you'll use queries include:
- Log Analytics: Use this primary tool in the Azure portal to edit log queries and interactively analyze their results. Even if you intend to use a log query elsewhere in Azure Monitor, you'll typically write and test it in Log Analytics before you copy it to its final location.

Selected Answer: C
C. a Log Analytics workspace

Selected Answer: C
C. a Log Analytics workspace
C is the correct answer

Selected Answer: C
Key phrase: ✑ Support querying events by using the Kusto query language.
correct

comments.content: This question doesn't make sense, so it could be outdated! You don't use New-AzStorageAccountKeys if you want to use user-managed keys.

discussion.content:
New-AzStorageAccount
New-AzStorageAccountKey
New-AzStorageTable

Why would you have to regenerate the access key ? Is this a mistake ? You need to generate a Keyvault encryption key when you use customer provided keys, NOT storage account keys. Should be Add-AzKeyvVaultKey commandlet... I do not get why we need to regen SA key at all since tney get created when you issue the New-AzStorageAccount commandlet. It's not like the existing key has been compromised...

This is very confusing, since New-AzStorageAccountKey is used to generage a key access key for storage account instead of encrytion key, for encryption you only need to run New-AzStorageAccount
New-AzStorageAccount -ResourceGroupName <resource_group> `
 -AccountName <storage-account> `
 -Location <location> `
 -SkuName "Standard_RAGRS" `
 -Kind StorageV2 `
 -EncryptionKeyTypeForTable Account `
 -EncryptionKeyTypeForQueue Account

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/az.storage/new-azstorageaccountkey?view=azps-9.2.0
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/account-encryption-key-create?tabs=powershell

comments.content: But, the question is 'You need to use customer-managed keys to encrypt the tables in the storage account'. so the answer is right.
You are right, I did not notice that. Then the answer might be correct. Anyway, this question is a bit strange for MS security exam.
read the line "You need to use customer-managed keys to encrypt the TABLES in the storage account"

discussion.content:
Following the given link for explanation it seems that the last option is not correct. It should be "Set-AzStorageAccount" instead (which is missing so it can not be chosen). 
Also what sense it would make to deal with Azure Tables in this scenario, right?
Correct Answer

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have an Azure subscription.
You plan to create a storage account.
You need to use customer-managed keys to encrypt the tables in the storage account.
From Azure Cloud Shell, which three cmdlets should you run in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate cmdlets from the list of cmdlets to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

HOTSPOT -
You have an Azure subscription that contains the following resources:
✑ An Azure key vault
✑ An Azure SQL database named Database1
Two Azure App Service web apps named AppSrv1 and AppSrv2 that are configured to use system-assigned managed identities and access Database1
//IMG//

You need to implement an encryption solution for Database1 that meets the following requirements:
✑ The data in a column named Discount in Database1 must be encrypted so that only AppSrv1 can decrypt the data.
✑ AppSrv1 and AppSrv2 must be authorized by using managed identities to obtain cryptographic keys.
How should you configure the encryption settings for Database1? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

comments.content: After reviewing that link you provided I will agree with you. Thank you.

discussion.content:
Always Encrypted by Using Azure Key Vault

Create an Access Policy in azure Key vault

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/database/always-encrypted-azure-key-vault-configure?tabs=azure-powershell#create-a-key-vault-to-store-your-keys

1. Always Encrypted by Using Azure Key Vault
2. Create an Access Policy in Azure Key Vault

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/security/encryption/always-encrypted-tutorial-getting-started

Always Encrypted by Using Azure Key Vault Create an Access Policy in azure Key vault
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/database/always-encrypted-azure-key-vault-configure? tabs=azure-powershell#create-a-key-vault-to-store-your-keys
in exam 13 Oct

Always Encrypted and Keyvault access policy.
For info on TDE vS Alawys Encrypted go read: https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/transparent-data-encryption-or-always-encrypted/

Always Encrypted by Using Azure Key Vault
Create an Access Policy in azure Key vault

Given answer is worng!

Correct answser 
1) Always encrypted using AKV
2) Create an Access policy
# In Exam 01-Oct-2022.

from the Link given by C6H6

Now that your client app is configured and you have your application ID, it's time to create a key vault and configure its access policy so you and your application can access the vault's secrets (the Always Encrypted keys). 

So I agree, that is should be box 1: Always Encrypted by Using Azure Key Vault

 box 2: reate an Access Policy in azure Key vault

1) Always encrypted using AKV
2) Create an Access policy

Transparent Data Encryption works on the database level and not on the column level. Therefore the first answer has to be: "Always Encrypted by Using Azure Key Vault"
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/database/transparent-data-encryption-tde-overview?tabs=azure-portal

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have an Azure subscription that contains the storage accounts shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You need to configure authorization access.
Which authorization types can you use for each storage account? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

comments.content:
Azure Service Shared Key Shared Access Signature (SAS) Azure AD
Azure Blob Storage Supported Supported Supported
Azure Files (SMB) Supported Not supported Supported
Azure Tables Storage Supported Supported Supported

discussion.content:
Azure Blobs - Shared Key, Shared Access Signature (SAS), Azure Active Directory (AAD)
Azure Files SMB - Shared Key only
Azure Tables - Shared Key, Shared Access Signature (SAS), Azure Active Directory (AAD)

storage1: Shared Key, SAS and Azure AD
storage2: Shared Key only
storage3: Shared Key, SAS and Azure AD

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/authorize-data-access

Hello.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/authorize-data-access?tabs=tables
Azure Blobs - Shared Key, Shared Access Signature (SAS), Azure Active Directory (AAD)
Azure Files SMB - Shared Key only
Azure Tables - Shared Key, Shared Access Signature (SAS), Azure Active Directory (AAD)
According to the link above, Azure tables
Shared access signature (SAS) User delegation SAS isn't supported for Table Storage. To learn more, see Using shared access signatures (SAS). Microsoft doesn't recommend using SAS tokens secured by the account key.

given ans is correct 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/modules/security-storage/3-authorize-requests-azure-storage

To support the answers.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/authorize-data-access?tabs=tables.

Azure Blobs - Shared Key, Shared Access Signature (SAS), Azure Active Directory (AAD) Azure Files SMB - Shared Key only
Azure Tables - Shared Key, Shared Access Signature (SAS), Azure Active Directory (AAD) Reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/authorize-data-access

The GIVEN ANSWER R CORRECT:

File share can be accessed via Storage explorer using SAS
but i guess it says SMB i believe thats why its only SHARED KEY???? correct me if wrong?

comments.content: got it! SAS access is not supported for SMB

discussion.content:
Answer is Correct,
Azure Blobs - Shared Key, Shared Access Signature, Azure Active Directory
Azure Files SMB - Shared Key
Azure Tables - Shared Key, Shared Access Signature, Azure Active Directory (Preview)

comments.content: Also Azure SMB files already supports AD (although with ADDS only). See Q41.

discussion.content: Correct. However for Table Storage, AD option is still under preview...But still the answer is correct.

Answer seem correct based on the provided link:
 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/authorize-data-access
